messageBody:
Kevin,

It sounds like you are frustrated, which makes sense since JUnit 4 is
advertised as being forward and backward compatible. JUnit4TestAdapter works
with some test runners, but not with Ant 1.6. Having talked with the Ant
team, my understanding is that Ant 1.7 is the first time they will have
JUnit 4 compatibility. One possibility is that you could find out how Ant
1.6 gets the name of the test and see if you can implement that interface in
the adapter.

Sincerely yours,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute


_____

From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
Kevin C. Dorff
Sent: Sunday, June 11, 2006 8:27 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] JUnit 4.1, running tests from and 1.6



So, with JUnit 4, if you have to use Ant 1.7 for it to know the names of
your test cases, what is the point of JUnit4TestAdapter which STATES it
makes JUnit4 backwards compatible with Ant 1.6. Why not just say JUnit 4
does NOT work with Ant 1.6? If using Ant 1.6 it won't tell me which tests
fails, JUnit 4 is NOT compatible and JUnit4TestAdapter was a waste of some
coders time.

What is going on or what am I missing?

Kevin

On 6/9/06, Jan Cumps <j_cumps@yahoo. <mailto:j_cumps%40yahoo.com> com>
wrote:
>
> Kevin, Srikant,
>
> I was able to run JUnit 4 in Ant 1.6.5 by checking out the latest version
> of Ant (1.7alpha) and building it from source (takes approx 15 minutes).
>
> Then I copied some files to the Ant 1.6.5 folders (after backing up the
> originals):
> etc/junit-frames.xsl
> etc/junit-noframes.xsl
>
> lib/ant-junit.jar
>
> junit 4 or 4.1 has to be in your classpath (or in the lib/ dir), junit
3.8not
>
> This allows me to run junit4 tests, native mode, in my netbeans 5
> installation.
>
> Regards, Jan
